Members of Famous Class Turned Out in
Force for Their Decennial Reunion
Held During the Holidays.

G. Pitts Raleigh Thrilled All His Auditors With a Masterful Oration—A
Strong Schedule Announced.

Chauncey Olcott's New Play "The Isle
o'Dreams" Very Popular — Big
Hopkins Turnout Expected.

By Edwin Lucas White.

Lacrosse prospects and plans for
the coming season were eloquently
set forth by a brilliant array of
speakers at the organization meeting held in the cage on Tuesday
afternoon, December To. All the
speeches were decidedly optimistic
and the large number of candidates
present manifested a lively interest
in everything that was said.
Captain John G. Huck presided.
He first called on Reaney Wolfe,
who was recently elected head coach
of this year's twelve. Coach Wolfe
made a brief but pointed speech and
emphasized the fact that all the positions on the teams were open and
would be filled only by the candidates who make the best showing
during the next two months, regardless of the fact that thirteen
"H" men are trying for the team.
G. Pitts Raleigh, B. . S., head
coach of the 1911 championship
twelve and one of the present lacrosse advisers, entertained all present with a most rhetorical and oratorical effusion which sparkled with
wit and humor. Assuming melodramatic pose he thundered, "Do
my Apollo-like knees beneath me
quake? Does my heart within me
shiver and shake? Does my Herculean breast palpitate because the
sporting editor of the Evening Sun
has dared to accuse me of being
the guy who put my foot in the
fotball team? No! Again, most
emphatically, no!" The great orator then proceeded to unfold the
glorious future that awaits the 1913
Hopkins lacrosse team. His matchless eloquence was at its best. He
so far surpassed all his famous previous efforts that the writer finds
it impossible to render him full justice. Suffice it to say he painted the
future of the lacrosse team in tones
so dazzling as to cause the pallescent tints of heaven's blue vault or
the half-revealed colors of fading
rainbows to seem the work of a
mere tyro.
"Father Bill" Schmeisser, Dr. Roland T. Abercrombie, Eddie Hulbert and Bob Lowndes each made a
short address before the meeting
was over. All the candidates present were signed up as members of
the squad.
Manager Howell has completed
his lacrosse schedule. All the
games are expected to be played on
the following dates, although several of the contracts have not
been signed. The schedule follows:
March 29, Johns Hopkins Alumni
at Homewood; April 5, Cornell at

There will be a "Hopkins Night"
performance at Ford's Theatre tomorrow night at one of the most
attractive productions that has appeared in Baltimore this year—"The
Isle 'o Dreams," with Chauncey 01cott. The play has an Irish scene,
and Mr. Olcott is, of course, the
star, with his tenor voice which has
made him one of the most popular players upon the American
stage. Rida Johnson Young is the
author. The action of the play
takes place in 1799, at the ,time of
the threatened invasion of England
and Ireland by Emperor Napoleon.
The story involves the fortunes
of Ivor Kelway, whose role is taken
by Mr. Olcott, a castaway picked up
off the coast of the Isle 'o Dreams,
a little island near the southern
coast of Ireland. He is adopted by
'Al other Kelway, who keeps the
tavern, and grows up under her
care to be a spirited and likely lad.
He then falls in love with Kathleen,
the (laughter of the rich and powerful O'Doons.
He takes part in all the thrilling
adventures of the times, many of
them for love's sake, and finally,
through a series of happenings, he
is discovered to be of a noble family
and heir to great wealth.
The greatest attraction, to some
of the theatre-gbers at least, will
be the number of songs, both old
and new, which are sung during
the performance. There are four
new songs which are most popular:
"When Irish Eyes Are Smiling,"
'The Isle 'o Dreams," "Kathleen
A'Roon" and "Mother Machree."
All are sung by Mr. Olcott.
For this play, special attention has been put upon the costuming and the scenery. The costumes
are most attractive and are all in
perfect keeping with the period,
while the scenery is said to be the
most elaborate and beautiful that
has ever been used for an Irish play
of this character.
A special musical program has
been arranged for the intermissions,
as follows:

"Ben dikkai
Deen dikka
Fatta dikka foo
Hopkins, Hopkins,
Nineteen-two."

It was thus that Homewood received the stamp of approval of the
representatives of the Class of 1902
at their decennial reunion on December 27, 1912. After enjoying
luncheon provided' by President
"Billy" Sneeringer at his home,
1317 North Charles street, the men
were taken to Homewood and noted
with enthusiasm the great strides
that have already been made, especially in the athletic field.
The Green Spring Valley Hunt
Club was next visited in order to
arouse an appetite for the dinner at
the University Club at 7 P. M.
Just, prior to the dinner an election of officers for the ensuing five
years was held. Ogle Marbury was
unanimously elected president and
Ralph C. Sharretts re-elected secretary-treasurer.
Those at the dinner were: Joseph
T. England, William B. Hill, Edward Badart, honorary , member
Dr. William Kirk of Rochester, N.
Y., William H. Koppelman of
Louisville, Ky., Ogle Marbury,
Charles Markell, Bartgis McGlone,
Charles A. Myers, Dr. Marbury B.
Ogle of Burlington, Vt., Aubrey
Pearre, Dr. Isaac R. Pels, Charles
Reider of York, Pa., William C.
Schmeisser, R. C. Sharretts, William J. Sneeringer, Jr., Dr. Harvey
B. Stone, Lewis J. White, Dr.
Samuel Wolman and Dr. Peregrine
Wroth of Hagerstown, Md.
Dr. Kirk was chosen toastmaster
and letters of regret from absent
members of the class were heard
with interest. A poll of those present indicated a large number of
prospective Hopkins students.
That the class still maintains its
interest in college life is evidenced
by its representation on the lacrosse,
football and track committees of the
graduate advisory committee. Ogle
Marbury's activities in the House of
Delegates on behalf of Hopkins in
its fight for a technical school were
warmly commended. Contrary to
its custom of landing first in any
competitive effort, it took second
place of all the classes of the University in the proportion of the
members who subscribed to the endowment fund; thus illustrating the
interest of the class if not its opulence.
Dr. Kirk was compelled to leave
before the dinner was over and

Dr. William Hand Browne I first
saw in the winter of 1877-78, or in
the spring of the latter year. I was
then a boarding pupil at Pen Lucy
School on the Old York road, beyond Waverly, which belonged to
Colonel Richard Malcolm Johnston,
the Georgia author of short stories.
One Saturday or Sunday Dr.
Browne dined there and I retained
a small boy's impression of a kindly man of middle height, with an
almost hunch-backed stoop, clad in
a suit of pepper-and-salt gray, and
frequently stroking a pointed beard.
Pen Lucy was then a wooded
country place of some nine acres,
the house a frame villa with much
outside scroll-sawed "decoration,"
all painted in dark hues. I seem to
recall seeing. seated together on its
ample porches Dr. Browne, Colonel
Johnston and Alexander H. Stephens, on a later occasion when the
ex-Vice-President of the Confederacy visited his Georgia friend.
For several years afterwards I
was a day pupil at the same school,
then housed over a grocery store
at the corner of North and Maryland avenues. According to the
then prevailing school fashion each
desk held two boys. I shared a
desk for most of the time with one
of Dr. Browne's sons, they then living at Charles and Twenty-fifth
streets. My desk-mate showed me
one of his exercises in Greek prose
compbsition, with corrections in his
father's handwriting. Boyishly, I
declared my Greek letters better
shaped than Dr. Browne's. The
next day my desk-mate brought
with him to school some carefully
written lines of Greek, one of the
most beautiful specimens of calligraphy I have ever seen. About
that time I was often at his house
with my school-fellows and I remember ,him in the evenings, seated
in the parlor, undisturbed by our
chatter and noise, evenly at work
on his translation of Von Falke's
"Greece and Rome." This was published in 1881—a large, handsome
illustrated gift book. That Christmas it was given me as a Christmas
present. I read it greedily and
noted on page 195, after several
mentions of Hannibal and of Alexander the Great, the misprint "even
before Alexander's death" for "even
before Hannibal's death." I told
my desk-mate and next day received
a note of thanks, written gravely,
as to an equal. The incident attracted his attention to me, and
from that time, when I was at his
house, I was likely to slide in(Continued on page 6, col. I.)

William Hand Browne, professor emeritus of English literature at
Johns Hopkins University, whose
death occurred on the thirteenth of
last month, was born in Baltimore
in i88. He passed his childhood
and youth quietly with his parents
in Baltimore. He was noted during his student days for his great
love for history, especially Maryland history, and literature, and for
a desire to master all the details of
both subjects. He made his first
appearance in public as the editor
of the Southern Magazine, to the
head of which he had been called
because of the clearness and beauty
of several magazine articles he had
'written before the time of his appointment. Although Dr. Browne
brought the magazine up to a high
level of literary attainment, it was
found impossible to continue its
publication owing to the uncertain
temper of the times. His Macaulian
knowledge of history and literature
fitted him pre-eminently for the position of librarian in the new Hopkins University, and in 1879 he was
offered this position.. But in 188o,

First 1912 Reunion.

The first reunion of the Class of

1912 was held on the night of De-

cember 30. As it was felt that their
senior year banquet had reached the
zenith of hotel banquets, President
Donald Belt spent much energy preparing a unique entertainment. By
advertisement he secured for that
evening the use of a fine old colonial
house in the suburbs, well provided
with large rooms and open log fireplaces.
A private car was provided to take
twenty-five members of the class to
the place of reunion. The house was
handsomely decorated with holly;
the banquet table and the electric
lights were harmoniously blended in
a color scheme of red and the place
cards were tastefully adorned with
tbe University seal. The excellence
of the courses urged on the speakers of the evening, one of whom
was Brooke Price, who had come
all the way from the Harvard Law
School in order to be present. Some
time was consumed in the discussion of class plans and, among other
things, it was voted that hereafter
reunions be held yearly, immediately
following Commencement Day.
After the banquet a pleasant evening was spent close by the log-filled
fireplace, where the bearded graduates of '12 with memory and fancy
interwoven told of things past,
present and future. Alfred Hatch
spoke of the mysteries of insurance,
Lindsay Rogers of newspaper
"beats," and Belt and Price gave
hints on traveling abroad, in short,
they all made merry until twelve
o'clock.

LIEBENSPERGER CAPTAIN
Heavy Tackle of Past Two Seasons to
Lead Next Year's Football Team.

At the meeting of this year's
'Varsity football team on December
12, Raymond Liebensperger, '14,
was elected captain. D. Penniman
and Branham were the other nominees, but the vote was not close.
Liebensperger was the logical choice
for the honor on account of his excellent work during the past two
years.
Somehow or other, during his
freshman year, Liebensperger did.
not play football, and it was not
until the annual game between the
sophomores and freshmen that his
ability became known. He was the
freshman fullback in that memorable game when the first year men
'beat the sophomores who had a
team of 'Varsity players. Liebensperger's line plunging in that game
was its feature, and in the interclass
game the next year Liebensperger
made two of the four touchdowns
scored by the 1914 team.
As a sophomore he was the regular left tackle and played every minute of the season save two, when he
was removed from the Thanksgiving Day game to allow a substitute to go in. He repeated this feat
again during the past season, only
this time his shoulder was wrenched
in the last few minutes of play in
the V. M. I. game. A very more.
disastrous season than Hopkins had
this year might have been recorded
if it were not for Liehensperger's
phenomenal 1)laying on the left side
of the line. Infrequently he broke

'BALTIMORE, MD., JAN. 6, 1913
Editor for this issue (C. Leland Getz).
1913.

To the subscribers, readers, advertisers and all persons interested
in THE NEWS-LETTER, the Editors
extend their best wishes for a most
happy and prosperous New Year.
May 1913 prove a banner year for
Johns Hopkins and all connected
with it!
- The New Year will witness the
active beginning of the construction of Hopkins' future buildings
at Homewood. Before another 365
days have passed by, several of the
main buildings should be nearing
completion, and the others will be
commenced upon as soon as all
the details are worked out by the
committees in charge.
Although the newly-established
technical school received first year
students last fall, because not much
change was requirea from the regular freshman work for the bachelor's degree, yet 1913 will really
mark the• formal opening of the
technical school as a distinctive department of the University. In all
probability the faculty of the technical school will be definitely decided
upon in a ,short time. It would, of
course, be too much to expect the
same degree of perfection at once
in the technical school as. obtains
at present in the other University
departments, but it is hoped that
it will not be long before the technical school takes the same high rank
in its field that the other departments hold in theirs.
Nineteen-thirteen will be an auspicious year for Hopkins because it
will mark the inauguration of
Woodrow Wilson, Johns Hopkins'
first alumnus to be elected to the
presidency of the United States.
May his administration be so emi.nently successful that Johns Hop-

Nineteen-thirteen gives every indication of being one of the best years
from an all-around sporting viewpoint that Johns Hopkins has ever
had. The Black and Blue lacrosse
team seems to be slated for another
championship, and the lacrosse
schedule is the best that has been
arranged for a number of years.
Hopkins will play every team in
both divisions of the Intercollegiate
Lacrosse League, and also the Navy
and Carlisle Indian twelves. All
but one of last year's baseball players are back at the University, and
there are a number of new candidates in the freshman class. Last
year's nine made a splendid record
and this year's team is expected to
do even better. The track team
will have a hard task excelling last
year's team, but the veterans and
new candidates are very optimistic
and are working hard. There is
certain to be a decided improvement
in football. The beneficial results
of the new system inaugurated last
year should begin to materialize
next fall. Hopkins will be represented by a basket ball team for the
first time in the history of the University, and the initial game will be
played early this month. Another
tennis team will be organized,.and
the tennis players expect to duplicate the successful record of the
tennis team last spring.

THE NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 6, 1913.
THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.
Cotillon Suggestion.

December 9, 1912.
To

the Editor of THE NEws-LETTER :

I have noticed that after every
Hopkins cotillon there is a great
confusion when the gentlemen try
to get their hats, shoes and overcoats. I suggest that the Cotillon
Board look into this matter. I, personally, do not see why the gentlemen must check their wraps. Why
can't the gentlemen have a room to
themselves as the ladies have? Then
we could take off our wraps, place
them on chairs and have no trouble
or confusion in procuring them
after the dance. In this way we
could get our wraps and be ready
.to escort our ladies home, instead
of having them wait a half hour or
more for us impolite escorts. I
have even noticed some of the ladies
taking the wraps of their escorts
into the ladies' room, because they
were afraid that, owing to the confusion at the men's room, they
might miss the last car home.
Surely the present checking system
is not used for fear that one boy
might steal the coat of another.
Surely a boy who can and is willing to pay to attend the dances does

not wish to steal. a coat. If the
ladies can be trusted, why can't their
escorts, the students themselves, be
trusted? If the checking system is
a money-making scheme for the
janitors, let the Cotillon Board give
each janitor seventy-five cents to
keep a watchful eye over the boys'
wraps. But I urge the Cotillon
Board to do away with the confusion, if it is impossible to free
us of the present checking system.
Yours truly,
GERHARD SCHMEISSER.
Dr. Abercrombie Honored.

Dr. Roland T. Abercrombie, director of the University's athletics,
was elected to the National Collegiate Athletic Association last week.
This Association being composed of
many of the country's most prominent figures in sports wields a heavy
influence in all movements for the
betterment of sports. The Association does not have executive power,
but its suggestions in an advisory
way are always accepted. One hundred and six colleges are represented, the number being divided into
conferences. Maryland is in the
southern conference.
Mr. Brevier of New Brunswick
is president, having been chosen to
succeed Captain Palmer Pierce,
U. S. A., who resigned when he
was ordered to the Philippines.

THE NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 6, 1913.
Niles Gets Scholarship.

Emory Hamilton Niles, w a s
awarded t h e Maryland Rhodes
Scholarship for the three years beginning October, 1913, at a meeting of the Maryland Rhodes Scholarship Committee of Selection recently in the office of President Ira
Remsen of the Johns Hopkins University.
The committee is composed of
Dr. Rem s en (chairman), Dr.
Thomas H. Lewis, president of
Western Maryland College, and Dr.
Thomas Fell, president of St. John's
College. •
:File decision was arrived at after
a lengthy consultation by the committee and only after the candidates
had been personally questioned by
the members of the committee:
Niles was one of the two candidates who were successful in the
qualifying examination last October. C. Leland Getz was the other
to qualify. Bertram Benedict, who
passed the qualifying examination
in 1910, and Mont Roger Reid, who
qualified in 1909, asked to be reconsidered for this year's appointment, as they are both under the
required age limit. The committee
made its selection from among these
four eligible candidates.
The scholarship was given Niles
because, in the judgment of the
committee, he best represented the
type of all-round man that the
founder,of the scholarships, the late
Cecil Rhodes of England and South
Africa, had in mind.
Regard was had by the committee to the literary and scholastic attainments of each of the candidates
and also to their fondness for and
success in athletics, their manly and
moral characteristics and their ability for leadership.
• The scholarship is worth $1,500
a year to the holder, and is tenable
for three years. Out of this the
holder has to pay his tuition, all
expenses pertaining to his stay at
Oxford and any traveling expenses
that may be incurred during vacation time. The scholars are supposed to visit France, Germany,
Italy and Switzerland during some
Of their vacations from Oxford.
Young Niles is the son of former Judge Alfred S. Niles, now one
of the Police Commissioners of
Baltimore. He made an excellent
record in his studies at Hopkins,
besides having played on the lacrosse team and taken part in other
student activities.
He is a member of the present
senior class at Hopkins. He is tall
and well built and 20 years old.
Niles is popluar with the students
and also with the Hopkins faculty.
Before entering Hopkins he was
graduated from the Polytechnic
Institute, standing second in a class
of more than 50.
President Remsen Improving.

President Ira Remsen is recovering rapidly from the operation performed by Dr. Hugh Young in
Johns Hopkins Hospital last week,
and he expects to resume his duties
at the University in a few days.

Members of Famous Class Turned Out in

Held During the Holidays.

G. Pitts Raleigh Thrilled All His Auditors With a Masterful Oration—A
Strong Schedule Announced.

Chauncey Olcott's New Play "The Isle
o'Dreams" Very Popular — Big
Hopkins Turnout Expected.

By Edwin Lucas White.

Lacrosse prospects and plans for
the coming season were eloquently
set forth by a brilliant array of
speakers at the organization meeting held in the cage on Tuesday
afternoon, December To. All the
speeches were decidedly optimistic
and the large number of candidates
present manifested a lively interest
in everything that was said.
Captain John G. Huck presided.
He first called on Reaney Wolfe,
who was recently elected head coach
of this year's twelve. Coach Wolfe
made a brief but pointed speech and
emphasized the fact that all the positions on the teams were open and
would be filled only by the candidates who make the best showing
during the next two months, regardless of the fact that thirteen
"H" men are trying for the team.
G. Pitts Raleigh, B. . S., head
coach of the 1911 championship
twelve and one of the present lacrosse advisers, entertained all present with a most rhetorical and oratorical effusion which sparkled with
wit and humor. Assuming melodramatic pose he thundered, "Do
my Apollo-like knees beneath me
quake? Does my heart within me
shiver and shake? Does my Herculean breast palpitate because the
sporting editor of the Evening Sun
has dared to accuse me of being
the guy who put my foot in the
fotball team? No! Again, most
emphatically, no!" The great orator then proceeded to unfold the
glorious future that awaits the 1913
Hopkins lacrosse team. His matchless eloquence was at its best. He
so far surpassed all his famous previous efforts that the writer finds
it impossible to render him full justice. Suffice it to say he painted the
future of the lacrosse team in tones
so dazzling as to cause the pallescent tints of heaven's blue vault or
the half-revealed colors of fading
rainbows to seem the work of a
mere tyro.
"Father Bill" Schmeisser, Dr. Roland T. Abercrombie, Eddie Hulbert and Bob Lowndes each made a
short address before the meeting
was over. All the candidates present were signed up as members of
the squad.
Manager Howell has completed
his lacrosse schedule. All the
games are expected to be played on
the following dates, although several of the contracts have not
been signed. The schedule follows:
March 29, Johns Hopkins Alumni
at Homewood; April 5, Cornell at

There will be a "Hopkins Night"
performance at Ford's Theatre tomorrow night at one of the most
attractive productions that has appeared in Baltimore this year—"The
Isle 'o Dreams," with Chauncey 01cott. The play has an Irish scene,
and Mr. Olcott is, of course, the
star, with his tenor voice which has
made him one of the most popular players upon the American
stage. Rida Johnson Young is the
author. The action of the play
takes place in 1799, at the ,time of
the threatened invasion of England
and Ireland by Emperor Napoleon.
The story involves the fortunes
of Ivor Kelway, whose role is taken
by Mr. Olcott, a castaway picked up
off the coast of the Isle 'o Dreams,
a little island near the southern
coast of Ireland. He is adopted by
'Al other Kelway, who keeps the
tavern, and grows up under her
care to be a spirited and likely lad.
He then falls in love with Kathleen,
the (laughter of the rich and powerful O'Doons.
He takes part in all the thrilling
adventures of the times, many of
them for love's sake, and finally,
through a series of happenings, he
is discovered to be of a noble family
and heir to great wealth.
The greatest attraction, to some
of the theatre-gbers at least, will
be the number of songs, both old
and new, which are sung during
the performance. There are four
new songs which are most popular:
"When Irish Eyes Are Smiling,"
'The Isle 'o Dreams," "Kathleen
A'Roon" and "Mother Machree."
All are sung by Mr. Olcott.
For this play, special attention has been put upon the costuming and the scenery. The costumes
are most attractive and are all in
perfect keeping with the period,
while the scenery is said to be the
most elaborate and beautiful that
has ever been used for an Irish play
of this character.
A special musical program has
been arranged for the intermissions,
as follows:

Deen dikka
Fatta dikka foo
Hopkins, Hopkins,
Nineteen-two."

It was thus that Homewood received the stamp of approval of the
representatives of the Class of 1902
at their decennial reunion on December 27, 1912. After enjoying
luncheon provided' by President
"Billy" Sneeringer at his home,
1317 North Charles street, the men
were taken to Homewood and noted
with enthusiasm the great strides
that have already been made, especially in the athletic field.
The Green Spring Valley Hunt
Club was next visited in order to
arouse an appetite for the dinner at
the University Club at 7 P. M.
Just, prior to the dinner an election of officers for the ensuing five
years was held. Ogle Marbury was
unanimously elected president and
Ralph C. Sharretts re-elected secretary-treasurer.
Those at the dinner were: Joseph
T. England, William B. Hill, Edward Badart, honorary , member
Dr. William Kirk of Rochester, N.
Y., William H. Koppelman of
Louisville, Ky., Ogle Marbury,
Charles Markell, Bartgis McGlone,
Charles A. Myers, Dr. Marbury B.
Ogle of Burlington, Vt., Aubrey
Pearre, Dr. Isaac R. Pels, Charles
Reider of York, Pa., William C.
Schmeisser, R. C. Sharretts, William J. Sneeringer, Jr., Dr. Harvey
B. Stone, Lewis J. White, Dr.
Samuel Wolman and Dr. Peregrine
Wroth of Hagerstown, Md.
Dr. Kirk was chosen toastmaster
and letters of regret from absent
members of the class were heard
with interest. A poll of those present indicated a large number of
prospective Hopkins students.
That the class still maintains its
interest in college life is evidenced
by its representation on the lacrosse,
football and track committees of the
graduate advisory committee. Ogle
Marbury's activities in the House of
Delegates on behalf of Hopkins in
its fight for a technical school were
warmly commended. Contrary to
its custom of landing first in any
competitive effort, it took second
place of all the classes of the University in the proportion of the
members who subscribed to the endowment fund; thus illustrating the
interest of the class if not its opulence.

before the dinner was over and

Dr. William Hand Browne I first
saw in the winter of 1877-78, or in
the spring of the latter year. I was
then a boarding pupil at Pen Lucy
School on the Old York road, beyond Waverly, which belonged to
Colonel Richard Malcolm Johnston,
the Georgia author of short stories.
One Saturday or Sunday Dr.
Browne dined there and I retained
a small boy's impression of a kindly man of middle height, with an
almost hunch-backed stoop, clad in
a suit of pepper-and-salt gray, and
frequently stroking a pointed beard.
Pen Lucy was then a wooded
country place of some nine acres,
the house a frame villa with much
outside scroll-sawed "decoration,"
all painted in dark hues. I seem to
recall seeing. seated together on its
ample porches Dr. Browne, Colonel
Johnston and Alexander H. Stephens, on a later occasion when the
ex-Vice-President of the Confederacy visited his Georgia friend.
For several years afterwards I
was a day pupil at the same school,
then housed over a grocery store
at the corner of North and Maryland avenues. According to the
then prevailing school fashion each
desk held two boys. I shared a
desk for most of the time with one
of Dr. Browne's sons, they then living at Charles and Twenty-fifth
streets. My desk-mate showed me
one of his exercises in Greek prose
compbsition, with corrections in his
father's handwriting. Boyishly, I
declared my Greek letters better
shaped than Dr. Browne's. The
next day my desk-mate brought
with him to school some carefully
written lines of Greek, one of the
most beautiful specimens of calligraphy I have ever seen. About
that time I was often at his house
with my school-fellows and I remember ,him in the evenings, seated
in the parlor, undisturbed by our
chatter and noise, evenly at work
on his translation of Von Falke's
"Greece and Rome." This was published in 1881—a large, handsome
illustrated gift book. That Christmas it was given me as a Christmas
present. I read it greedily and
noted on page 195, after several
mentions of Hannibal and of Alexander the Great, the misprint "even
before Alexander's death" for "even
before Hannibal's death." I told
my desk-mate and next day received
a note of thanks, written gravely,
as to an equal. The incident attracted his attention to me, and
from that time, when I was at his
house, I was likely to slide in(Continued on page 6, col. I.)

William Hand Browne, professor emeritus of English literature at
Johns Hopkins University, whose
death occurred on the thirteenth of
last month, was born in Baltimore
in i88. He passed his childhood
and youth quietly with his parents
in Baltimore. He was noted during his student days for his great
love for history, especially Maryland history, and literature, and for
a desire to master all the details of
both subjects. He made his first
appearance in public as the editor
of the Southern Magazine, to the
head of which he had been called
because of the clearness and beauty
of several magazine articles he had
'written before the time of his appointment. Although Dr. Browne
brought the magazine up to a high
level of literary attainment, it was
found impossible to continue its
publication owing to the uncertain
temper of the times. His Macaulian
knowledge of history and literature
fitted him pre-eminently for the position of librarian in the new Hopkins University, and in 1879 he was
offered this position.. But in 188o,

First 1912 Reunion.

The first reunion of the Class of

1912 was held on the night of De-

cember 30. As it was felt that their
senior year banquet had reached the
zenith of hotel banquets, President
Donald Belt spent much energy preparing a unique entertainment. By
advertisement he secured for that
evening the use of a fine old colonial
house in the suburbs, well provided
with large rooms and open log fireplaces.
A private car was provided to take
twenty-five members of the class to
the place of reunion. The house was
handsomely decorated with holly;
the banquet table and the electric
lights were harmoniously blended in
a color scheme of red and the place
cards were tastefully adorned with
tbe University seal. The excellence
of the courses urged on the speakers of the evening, one of whom
was Brooke Price, who had come
all the way from the Harvard Law
School in order to be present. Some
time was consumed in the discussion of class plans and, among other
things, it was voted that hereafter
reunions be held yearly, immediately
following Commencement Day.
After the banquet a pleasant evening was spent close by the log-filled
fireplace, where the bearded graduates of '12 with memory and fancy
interwoven told of things past,
present and future. Alfred Hatch
spoke of the mysteries of insurance,
Lindsay Rogers of newspaper
"beats," and Belt and Price gave
hints on traveling abroad, in short,
they all made merry until twelve
o'clock.

LIEBENSPERGER CAPTAIN
Heavy Tackle of Past Two Seasons to
Lead Next Year's Football Team.

At the meeting of this year's
'Varsity football team on December
12, Raymond Liebensperger, '14,
was elected captain. D. Penniman
and Branham were the other nominees, but the vote was not close.
Liebensperger was the logical choice
for the honor on account of his excellent work during the past two
years.
Somehow or other, during his
freshman year, Liebensperger did.
not play football, and it was not
until the annual game between the
sophomores and freshmen that his
ability became known. He was the
freshman fullback in that memorable game when the first year men
'beat the sophomores who had a
team of 'Varsity players. Liebensperger's line plunging in that game
was its feature, and in the interclass
game the next year Liebensperger
made two of the four touchdowns
scored by the 1914 team.
As a sophomore he was the regular left tackle and played every minute of the season save two, when he
was removed from the Thanksgiving Day game to allow a substitute to go in. He repeated this feat
again during the past season, only
this time his shoulder was wrenched
in the last few minutes of play in
the V. M. I. game. A very more.
disastrous season than Hopkins had
this year might have been recorded
if it were not for Liehensperger's
phenomenal 1)laying on the left side
of the line. Infrequently he broke

'BALTIMORE, MD., JAN. 6, 1913
Editor for this issue (C. Leland Getz).
1913.

To the subscribers, readers, advertisers and all persons interested
in THE NEWS-LETTER, the Editors
extend their best wishes for a most
happy and prosperous New Year.
May 1913 prove a banner year for
Johns Hopkins and all connected
with it!
- The New Year will witness the
active beginning of the construction of Hopkins' future buildings
at Homewood. Before another 365
days have passed by, several of the
main buildings should be nearing
completion, and the others will be
commenced upon as soon as all
the details are worked out by the
committees in charge.
Although the newly-established
technical school received first year
students last fall, because not much
change was requirea from the regular freshman work for the bachelor's degree, yet 1913 will really
mark the• formal opening of the
technical school as a distinctive department of the University. In all
probability the faculty of the technical school will be definitely decided
upon in a ,short time. It would, of
course, be too much to expect the
same degree of perfection at once
in the technical school as. obtains
at present in the other University
departments, but it is hoped that
it will not be long before the technical school takes the same high rank
in its field that the other departments hold in theirs.
Nineteen-thirteen will be an auspicious year for Hopkins because it
will mark the inauguration of
Woodrow Wilson, Johns Hopkins'
first alumnus to be elected to the
presidency of the United States.
May his administration be so emi.nently successful that Johns Hop-

Nineteen-thirteen gives every indication of being one of the best years
from an all-around sporting viewpoint that Johns Hopkins has ever
had. The Black and Blue lacrosse
team seems to be slated for another
championship, and the lacrosse
schedule is the best that has been
arranged for a number of years.
Hopkins will play every team in
both divisions of the Intercollegiate
Lacrosse League, and also the Navy
and Carlisle Indian twelves. All
but one of last year's baseball players are back at the University, and
there are a number of new candidates in the freshman class. Last
year's nine made a splendid record
and this year's team is expected to
do even better. The track team
will have a hard task excelling last
year's team, but the veterans and
new candidates are very optimistic
and are working hard. There is
certain to be a decided improvement
in football. The beneficial results
of the new system inaugurated last
year should begin to materialize
next fall. Hopkins will be represented by a basket ball team for the
first time in the history of the University, and the initial game will be
played early this month. Another
tennis team will be organized,.and
the tennis players expect to duplicate the successful record of the
tennis team last spring.

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.
Cotillon Suggestion.

December 9, 1912.
To

the Editor of THE NEws-LETTER :

I have noticed that after every
Hopkins cotillon there is a great
confusion when the gentlemen try
to get their hats, shoes and overcoats. I suggest that the Cotillon
Board look into this matter. I, personally, do not see why the gentlemen must check their wraps. Why
can't the gentlemen have a room to
themselves as the ladies have? Then
we could take off our wraps, place
them on chairs and have no trouble
or confusion in procuring them
after the dance. In this way we
could get our wraps and be ready
.to escort our ladies home, instead
of having them wait a half hour or
more for us impolite escorts. I
have even noticed some of the ladies
taking the wraps of their escorts
into the ladies' room, because they
were afraid that, owing to the confusion at the men's room, they
might miss the last car home.
Surely the present checking system
is not used for fear that one boy
might steal the coat of another.
Surely a boy who can and is willing to pay to attend the dances does

not wish to steal. a coat. If the
ladies can be trusted, why can't their
escorts, the students themselves, be
trusted? If the checking system is
a money-making scheme for the
janitors, let the Cotillon Board give
each janitor seventy-five cents to
keep a watchful eye over the boys'
wraps. But I urge the Cotillon
Board to do away with the confusion, if it is impossible to free
us of the present checking system.
Yours truly,
GERHARD SCHMEISSER.
Dr. Abercrombie Honored.

Dr. Roland T. Abercrombie, director of the University's athletics,
was elected to the National Collegiate Athletic Association last week.
This Association being composed of
many of the country's most prominent figures in sports wields a heavy
influence in all movements for the
betterment of sports. The Association does not have executive power,
but its suggestions in an advisory
way are always accepted. One hundred and six colleges are represented, the number being divided into
conferences. Maryland is in the
southern conference.
Mr. Brevier of New Brunswick
is president, having been chosen to
succeed Captain Palmer Pierce,
U. S. A., who resigned when he
was ordered to the Philippines.

THE NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 6, 1913.
Niles Gets Scholarship.

Emory Hamilton Niles, w a s
awarded t h e Maryland Rhodes
Scholarship for the three years beginning October, 1913, at a meeting of the Maryland Rhodes Scholarship Committee of Selection recently in the office of President Ira
Remsen of the Johns Hopkins University.
The committee is composed of
Dr. Rem s en (chairman), Dr.
Thomas H. Lewis, president of
Western Maryland College, and Dr.
Thomas Fell, president of St. John's
College. •
:File decision was arrived at after
a lengthy consultation by the committee and only after the candidates
had been personally questioned by
the members of the committee:
Niles was one of the two candidates who were successful in the
qualifying examination last October. C. Leland Getz was the other
to qualify. Bertram Benedict, who
passed the qualifying examination
in 1910, and Mont Roger Reid, who
qualified in 1909, asked to be reconsidered for this year's appointment, as they are both under the
required age limit. The committee
made its selection from among these
four eligible candidates.
The scholarship was given Niles
because, in the judgment of the
committee, he best represented the
type of all-round man that the
founder,of the scholarships, the late
Cecil Rhodes of England and South
Africa, had in mind.
Regard was had by the committee to the literary and scholastic attainments of each of the candidates
and also to their fondness for and
success in athletics, their manly and
moral characteristics and their ability for leadership.
• The scholarship is worth $1,500
a year to the holder, and is tenable
for three years. Out of this the
holder has to pay his tuition, all
expenses pertaining to his stay at
Oxford and any traveling expenses
that may be incurred during vacation time. The scholars are supposed to visit France, Germany,
Italy and Switzerland during some
Of their vacations from Oxford.
Young Niles is the son of former Judge Alfred S. Niles, now one
of the Police Commissioners of
Baltimore. He made an excellent
record in his studies at Hopkins,
besides having played on the lacrosse team and taken part in other
student activities.
He is a member of the present
senior class at Hopkins. He is tall
and well built and 20 years old.
Niles is popluar with the students
and also with the Hopkins faculty.
Before entering Hopkins he was
graduated from the Polytechnic
Institute, standing second in a class
of more than 50.
President Remsen Improving.

President Ira Remsen is recovering rapidly from the operation performed by Dr. Hugh Young in
Johns Hopkins Hospital last week,
and he expects to resume his duties
at the University in a few days.
